channel.title: Talks By Russell M. Nelson
channel.description: General Conference talks by Russell M. Nelson.

item.title: Reverence for Life
item.description: Unitedly we thank the Almighty for the wondrous prolongation of the life of Elder Bruce R. McConkie, enabling him to preach that powerful sermon. Our gratitude is profound!

item.title: Self-Mastery
item.description: If our faith be united in prayer that we may be edified together, I should like to speak about our quest for self-mastery. In so doing, I would converse as a loving father counseling one of my own children.

item.title: In the Lord’s Own Way

item.title: “Joy Cometh in the Morning”
item.description: The title of my message is taken from the thirtieth Psalm, verse 5 []: “Joy cometh in the morning.” As I discussed this scripture with members of our family, they recalled that “men are, that they might have joy” (), but they had not pondered the int

item.title: Life after Life

item.title: Lessons from Eve
item.description: President and Sister Benson, I hope you can feel the love and spirit emanating from the thousands of sisters at this General Women’s Meeting. President Hinckley and President Monson, we extend our love to you and your companions. The attendance of me

item.title: Keys of the Priesthood
item.description: You all know how valuable keys can be. Many, if not most, of us carry keys in our pockets at this very moment.

item.title: “With God Nothing Shall Be Impossible”
item.description: I echo the testimony of our beloved associate, Elder Dallin H. Oaks. With him and the other Brethren, I applaud the efforts of Latter-day Saints throughout the world who willingly serve in building the kingdom of God. Likewise, I respect those who qu

item.title: Addiction or Freedom
item.description: I am impressed to speak out on a problem of deep concern—the worldwide epidemic of drug addiction. As a medical doctor, my study of drugs began early in medical school. Each doctor spends months in specialized courses learning potential benefits and

item.title: The Canker of Contention
item.description: Some months ago my esteemed colleague Elder Carlos E. Asay and I stood atop Mount Nebo, where Moses once stood. (See .) We saw what he saw. In the distance to our right was the Sea of Galilee. The river Jordan flowed from there to the Dead Sea on our

item.title: Woman—Of Infinite Worth
item.description: Words are inadequate to express the gratitude we feel for these brethren who have just been released from active assignment as General Authorities of the Church. We appreciate their marvelous ministry and powerful influence for good in the world.

item.title: “Thus Shall My Church Be Called”
item.description: Today I would like to speak about a name. We are all pleased when our names are pronounced and spelled correctly. Sometimes a nickname is used instead of the real name. But a nickname may offend either the one named or the parents who gave the name.

item.title: Choices
item.description: Not long ago a beautiful young mother asked me for guidance with a very difficult decision she was facing. It pertained to an important surgical operation that was being considered. Consequences of her choice would affect her husband and her family a

item.title: Listen to Learn
item.description: In his invocation for this session of conference, Elder Hugh W. Pinnock prayed that we might listen carefully. Many articles in Church literature have dealt with the important art of listening. They support a proverb that teaches this vital lesson: “

item.title: “These … Were Our Examples”
item.description: In June of this year, Sister Nelson and I had the great privilege of accompanying the Mormon Tabernacle Choir on its historic concert tour in Europe. We are grateful to the First Presidency for that assignment. Much has been written regarding the suc

item.title: Doors of Death
item.description: This morning Elder Boyd K. Packer spoke of the “fountains of life.” This afternoon, I should like to speak of the “doors of death.” Both are crucial components of life.

item.title: Where Is Wisdom?
item.description: Today I would like to pose a question asked long ago by Job: “Where shall wisdom be found?” (.)

item.title: Honoring the Priesthood
item.description: Brethren, relatively little is written on my subject. Yet we are all expected to know about it. I speak of honoring the priesthood.

item.title: Constancy amid Change
item.description: I echo President Monson’s compliments to Brother Peterson, Brother Komatsu, and Brother de Jager. They have earned our greatest commendation. And I, too, join with others who feel a debt of gratitude to this wonderful chorus of youth from Brigham You

item.title: “Teach Us Tolerance and Love”
item.description: Dear brothers and sisters, I join my brethren in extending Easter greetings to each of you, while expressing personal gratitude for the atonement of Jesus Christ, for His example, and for His teachings that have motivated my message today.

item.title: The Spirit of Elijah
item.description: Within the past year, four of our beloved General Authorities have concluded their mission in mortality. The passing of President Ezra Taft Benson and Elders Marvin J. Ashton, Sterling W. Sill, and Clinton L. Cutler has prompted a great outpouring of

item.title: Children of the Covenant
item.description: The title of my message is the scriptural phrase “children of the covenant.” In introducing this topic I will reflect on recent events as a colleague of President Howard W. Hunter and as a father and upon earlier experiences as a doctor of medicine.

item.title: Perfection Pending
item.description: If I were to ask which of the Lord’s commandments is most difficult to keep, many of us might cite : “Be ye therefore perfect, even as your Father which is in heaven is perfect.”

item.title: “Thou Shalt Have No Other Gods”
item.description: As I face this congregation, I sense the responsibility entrusted to me. As you face the General Authorities and officers of the Church, you also bear responsibility. We are all accountable for acting upon the truths that are taught.

item.title: The Atonement
item.description: Humbly I join the Book of Mormon prophet Jacob, who asked, “Why not speak of the atonement of Christ?” This topic comprises our third article of faith: “We believe that through the Atonement of Christ, all mankind may be saved, by obedience to the la

item.title: Endure and Be Lifted Up
item.description: [The] responsibility to endure is uniquely yours. But you are never alone. I testify that the lifting power of the Lord can be yours.

item.title: Spiritual Capacity
item.description: We need an example—someone to show us how spiritual capacity can be developed. I have selected as a model … President Gordon B. Hinckley.

item.title: A New Harvest Time
item.description: A new era of family history work has arrived.

item.title: We Are Children of God
item.description: Who are we? We are children of God. Our potential is unlimited. Our inheritance is sacred.

item.title: Our Sacred Duty to Honor Women
item.description: Thank the Lord for these sisters who—like our Heavenly Father—love us not only for what we are but for what we may become.

item.title: A Testimony of the Book of Mormon
item.description: When you read the Book of Mormon, concentrate on the principal figure in the book—from its first chapter to the last—the Lord Jesus Christ.

item.title: The Creation
item.description: Grand as it is, planet Earth is part of something even grander—that great plan of God. Simply summarized, the earth was created that families might be.

item.title: Living by Scriptural Guidance
item.description: We all need guidance through life. We obtain it best from the standard works and teachings of the prophets of God.

item.title: Personal Preparation for Temple Blessings
item.description: Those who enter the temple are also to bear the attribute of holiness. … We can acquire holiness only by enduring and persistent personal effort.

item.title: “Set in Order Thy House”
item.description: Our family is the focus of our greatest work and joy in this life; so will it be throughout all eternity.

item.title: How Firm Our Foundation
item.description: The foundation of one’s individual faith, if anchored firmly to eternal truth, allows each of us to reach upward with an eternal perspective.

item.title: “Blessed Are the Peacemakers”
item.description: Peace is a prime priority that pleads for our pursuit.

item.title: Sweet Power of Prayer
item.description: We should pray in accord with the will of our Heavenly Father. He wants to test us, to strengthen us, and to help us achieve our full potential.

item.title: Personal Priesthood Responsibility
item.description: When ordained to an office in the priesthood, you are granted authority. But power comes from exercising that authority in righteousness.

item.title: Roots and Branches
item.description: Simply summarized, life’s greatest blessings will come to us if our love of Jesus Christ is rooted deeply in our hearts.

item.title: Senior Missionaries and the Gospel
item.description: I express gratitude for our senior missionaries. They are young in spirit, wise, and willing to work.

item.title: Now Is the Time to Prepare
item.description: Now is the time to prepare to meet God. Tomorrow may be too late.

item.title: Jesus Christ—the Master Healer
item.description: Faith, repentance, baptism, a testimony, and enduring conversion lead to the healing power of the Lord.

item.title: Nurturing Marriage
item.description: Marriages would be happier if nurtured more carefully.

item.title: The Gathering of Scattered Israel
item.description: We help to gather the elect of the Lord on both sides of the veil.

item.title: Repentance and Conversion
item.description: A repentant soul is a converted soul, and a converted soul is a repentant soul.

item.title: Scriptural Witnesses
item.description: Scriptures of the Restoration do not compete with the Bible; they complement the Bible.

item.title: Salvation and Exaltation
item.description: In God’s eternal plan, salvation is an individual matter; exaltation is a family matter.

item.title: Celestial Marriage
item.description: [The] proclamation on the family helps us realize that celestial marriage brings greater possibilities for happiness than does any other relationship.

item.title: Lessons from the Lord’s Prayers
item.description: Our prayers follow patterns and teachings of the Lord Jesus Christ. He taught us how to pray.

item.title: Ask, Seek, Knock
item.description: Every Latter-day Saint may merit personal revelation.

item.title: Generations Linked in Love
item.description: Our inborn yearnings for family connections are fulfilled when we are linked to our ancestors through sacred ordinances of the temple.

item.title: Be Thou an Example of the Believers
item.description: Whether full-time missionaries or members, we should all be good examples of the believers in Jesus Christ.

item.title: Face the Future with Faith
item.description: Truth, covenants, and ordinances enable us to overcome fear and face the future with faith!

item.title: Covenants
item.description: When we realize that we are children of the covenant, we know who we are and what God expects of us.

item.title: Thanks Be to God
item.description: How much better it would be if all could be more aware of God’s providence and love and express that gratitude to Him.

item.title: Ask the Missionaries! They Can Help You!
item.description: All missionaries, younger and older, serve with the sole hope of making life better for other people.

item.title: Catch the Wave
item.description: I thank God and His Son, Jesus Christ, for the Restoration and its power to propel a magnificent wave of truth and righteousness across the earth.

item.title: Decisions for Eternity
item.description: The wise use of your freedom to make your own decisions is crucial to your spiritual growth, now and for eternity.

item.title: Let Your Faith Show
item.description: Russell M. Nelson counsels us to increase our faith by living our religion. He encourages us not to hide our faith but to let it show.

item.title: Sustaining the Prophets
item.description: Elder Russell�M. Nelson testifies of the calling of the President of the Church and encourages Latter-day Saints to sustain the living prophets.

item.title: The Sabbath Is a Delight
item.description: Russell M. Nelson teaches how we can make the Sabbath a delight through strengthening family ties, doing family history work, and serving others.

item.title: A Plea to My Sisters
item.description: President Russell M. Nelson extols the contributions made by women to the Church and community. He encourages women to keep their covenants.

item.title: Joy and Spiritual Survival
item.description: President Nelson teaches that we can have joy in the midst of any circumstance if we are focused on Jesus Christ and the plan of salvation.

item.title: Drawing the Power of Jesus Christ into Our Lives
item.description: Elder Nelson teaches that we can draw the power of Jesus Christ into our lives as we learn of Him, have faith in Him, reach up to Him, and keep our covenants.
